titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Catherine Roraback Collection of Ericka Huggins Papers
Roraback (Catherine) Collection of Ericka Huggins Papers
titlestmt.author: by Afua Ferdnance

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday March 27, 2019 at 03:11

did.unittitle: Catherine Roraback Collection of Ericka Huggins Papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Catherine Roraback Collection of Ericka Huggins papers consists of materials compiled by attorney Catherine Roraback during the New Haven trial of Black Panther Party leader Ericka Huggins. Included in the collection are Huggins' legal files, prison writings, clippings, correspondence and other documentation of the trial and Huggins' imprisonment.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 10 contains restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Bolerium Books on the Elizabeth Wakeman Dwight Memorial Fund, 2012.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Ericka Huggins Trial Proceedings (1961-2000). II. Correspondence (1969-1972). III. Ericka Huggins Personal Papers (1969-1975).

bioghist.head: Catherine Roraback (1920-2007)
bioghist.p: Catherine Roraback was a Connecticut civil rights attorney who served as lead defense counsel for Ericka Huggins during her trial for the kidnapping and murder of Alex Rackley. Roraback was born on September 17, 1920 in Brooklyn, New York City, New York. She graduated from Mount Holyoke College in 1941 and was the only woman to graduate from Yale University Law School in 1948. Upon graduation, Roraback took over her family's law practice in Canaan, Connecticut. From 1969 to 1971, Roraback defended Ericka Huggins, a leader in the New Haven chapter of the Black Panther Party who was charged with conspiracy in the murder of Alex Rackley, a member of the Black Panther Party. On May 25 1971, the trial ended in a hung jury and was declared a mistrial. After the trial, Roraback continued to practice law and participated in organizations such as the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union, an organization she co-founded, and became president of the National Lawyers Guild. Roraback died on October 17, 2007 in Salisbury, Connecticut.

bioghist.head: Ericka Huggins (1948-)
bioghist.p: Ericka Jenkins Huggins was born in Washington D.C. on January 5, 1948. Huggins attended Lincoln University where she met her husband, John Huggins, and together they moved to California to join the Black Panther Party. John Huggins was murdered by members of the rival black nationalist US Organization on the University of California, Los Angeles campus in 1969. After his death, Huggins relocated to New Haven, Connecticut with their daughter Mai and became a leader in the New Haven chapter of the Black Panther Party. On May 22, 1969, Huggins, along with Black Panther Party co-founder Bobby Seale, faced charges that stemmed from the kidnapping and murder of Black Panther Party member Alex Rackley. The trial, which lasted from October 1970 to May 1971, ended in a mistrial and dismissal of all charges. Huggins was released on May 25, 1971. After the trial, Huggins remained in the Black Panther Party and became the director of the Oakland Community School in Oakland, California until 1981. She also became the first black woman and first woman to be appointed to the Alameda County Board of Education. Huggins also worked as a professor of sociology and African American studies in the Peralta Community College District.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Catherine Roraback Collection of Ericka Huggins Papers. James Weldon Johnson Collection in the Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials in the Catherine Roraback collection of Ericka Huggins papers document the activities of both Catherine Roraback and Ericka Huggins during the New Haven Black Panther trials. A majority of the collection contains Catherine Roraback's legal files related to Ericka Huggins's trial, including memoranda on prison conditions, statements, depositions, affidavits, and FBI reports. Materials belonging to Ericka Huggins includes poems, correspondence, and other writings created during her imprisonment. Communist reading material requested by Huggins such as The Selected Writings of Mao Tse-Tung (1968) are also included.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Catherine Roraback Collection of Ericka Huggins Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of Catherine Roraback's legal files documentating the trial of New Haven Black Panther Party leader Ericka Huggins. Trial statements made by members of the Black Panther Party include those from Ericka Huggins, George Sams, and Loretta Luckes. Copies of FBI files documenting the movements of the Black Panther party including a statement by former FBI director J. Edgar Hoover are contained within this series. The series also contains media covering the New Haven Black Panther Party Trial including press from the Panther Trial News , the Liberation News Service , and clippings from various news outlets such as The New Yorker , The New York Times , and The New Haven Register . A petition to free Ericka Huggins as well as memoranda and correspondence from lawyers and Yale Officials regarding the trial and Yale May Day protests are also included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Transcripts of tapes made during the interrogation of Alex Rackley with related notes and correspondence.

Suppression hearings, FBI subpoenas and motion to quash
Trial exhibit: Transcript of Bobby Seale's speech delivered at Battel Chapel Yale University

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes letters from Yale officials including Yale President Kingman Brewster, secretary Reuben A. Holden and dean of Yale Law School Louis H. Pollak to alumni and parents on issues relating to the Black Panther trials. A memorandum to the Yale community from the trial report committee providing a summary of the of the case is also included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes letters to and from Catherine Roraback and Ericka Huggins. Letters received by Ericka Huggins while she was imprisoned include one from Angela Davis. Letters to Black Panthers Landon Williams and Rory Hithe from Ericka Huggins are also included. Correspondence to and from Catherine Roraback documents interests in the trial and includes letters from lawyers such as Charles Garry, who defended Bobby Seale during the New Haven Black Panther trial.

did.unittitle: Correspondence to and from Ericka Huggins

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes letter to Michael (Mikel), a friend of Ericka Huggins.

did.unittitle: Correspondence to and from Catherine Roraback

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes the personal papers of Ericka Huggins and Catherine Roraback. Ericka Huggins papers document her time in prison. Poems and other writings written by Huggins about her imprisonment and the Black Panther Party are included. Requested reading materials include communist publications such as Selected Works of Mao Tse-Tung (1967). The series also contains documents related to the possible publishing of a book of poems by Ericka Huggins and Angela Davis. Catherine Roraback's personal papers consist of a painting entitled "Niantic" from Nancy Schulman.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 10 contains restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
